Spanish also includes words that do not change from singular to plural, such as lunes (Monday(s)) and paraguas (umbrella(s)). In Chinese, Hmong, and Vietnamese, there is no plural form for nouns. Students who speak these languages as their first language may need support and may benefit from practice forming plurals. Students whose first language is Cantonese, Hmong, Haitian Creole, Korean, or Vietnamese do not use a plural marker to signify more than one. If students do not use the plural when needed, restate the sentence modeling the correct form.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
/ square. Add a square to show me
Students should add a different color square after the purple /

Review closed syllables: Ends in a consonant and has a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants: pub/lic.

Review open syllables: Ends in a vowel and has a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide before and after the consonant, then blend the sounds and see which forms a word you have heard. Try before the consonant first: ba/sic.
Review vowel team syllables: The vowel team stays together in the same syllable, as in rea/son.
Review r-controlled syllables: The letters that make up the r-controlled syllable stay together in the same syllable, as in mar/gin.
Have students use the following words to identify and read the syllables and then blend the syllables to read the words: subject (sub/ject), vacant (va/cant), contain (con/tain), turkey (tur/key).

Spanish also includes words that do not change from singular to plural, such as lunes (Monday(s)) and paraguas (umbrella(s)). In Chinese, Hmong, and Vietnamese, there is no plural form for nouns. Students who speak these languages as their first language may need support and may benefit from practice forming plurals. Students whose first language is Cantonese, Hmong, Haitian Creole, Korean, or Vietnamese do not use a plural marker to signify more than one. If students do not use the plural when needed, restate the sentence modeling the correct form.

to review syllable types with students.

Model identifying the syllable types within each word and dividing the word into syllables. Then have students blend the syllables to read the word.
Review closed syllables: Ends in a consonant and has a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants: pub/lic.

Review open syllables: Ends in a vowel and has a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide before and after the consonant, then blend the sounds and see which forms a word you have heard. Try before the consonant first: ba/sic.
Review vowel team syllables: The vowel team stays together in the same syllable, as in rea/son.
Review r-controlled syllables: The letters that make up the r-controlled syllable stay together in the same syllable, as in mar/gin.
Have students use the following words to identify and read the syllables and then blend the syllables to read the words: subject (sub/ject), vacant (va/cant), contain (con/tain), turkey (tur/key).

Spanish also includes words that do not change from singular to plural, such as lunes (Monday(s)) and paraguas (umbrella(s)). In Chinese, Hmong, and Vietnamese, there is no plural form for nouns. Students who speak these languages as their first language may need support and may benefit from practice forming plurals. Students whose first language is Cantonese, Hmong, Haitian Creole, Korean, or Vietnamese do not use a plural marker to signify more than one. If students do not use the plural when needed, restate the sentence modeling the correct form.

Model identifying the syllable types within each word and dividing the word into syllables. Then have students blend the syllables to read the word.
Review closed syllables: Ends in a consonant and has a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants: pub/lic.

Review open syllables: Ends in a vowel and has a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide before and after the consonant, then blend the sounds and see which forms a word you have heard. Try before the consonant first: ba/sic.
Review vowel team syllables: The vowel team stays together in the same syllable, as in rea/son.
Review r-controlled syllables: The letters that make up the r-controlled syllable stay together in the same syllable, as in mar/gin.
Have students use the following words to identify and read the syllables and then blend the syllables to read the words: subject (sub/ject), vacant (va/cant), contain (con/tain), turkey (tur/key).
